2831.50.text:
over here has a hydroxyl
that is sort of interacting

2835.75.text:
with this CH20H
in carbon number 6.

2839.71.text: They're too close to each other.

2841.82.text:
We describe the structure
this guy has as a boat.

2844.53.text:
Because if we trace
the path of the carbons,

2849.12.text:
There and then down and
then across like this.

2852.03.text: It looks like a boat, all right?

2856.35.text: The same beta, this is beta,

2858.85.text: this is beta, they're both betas,

2862.37.text:
can twist bonds
and rearrange itself

2864.98.text:
so that that interaction
does not occur.

2869.12.text:
This is a beta form
like this is a beta form,

2870.92.text:
but this is a beta that
has a different confirmation

2873.81.text:
and it's flipped
itself so that hydroxyl

2875.41.text:
which was in the way up here
is flipped down over here.

2881.44.text:
And it should say
down equatorially

2886.79.text:
Now that configuration
is called the chair

2889.45.text:
because it has a sort of
configuration of a chaise lounge.

2892.66.text:
There's the back,
there's the butt end part,

2894.80.text:
and there's where
you put your feet.

2898.69.text:
Student: Yeah, over here,
that hydroxyl [inaudible].

2909.64.text:
Ahern: These two guys do
interact actually right here.

2913.50.text:
There's much more interaction
here than there is here.

2916.53.text:
And so this is favored
of the two structures.

2919.47.text:
The chair form is favored over
the boat form because of that.

2924.18.text: So if you compare this to this,

2926.25.text:
this has much more
interaction than this one does.

2929.70.text:

the chair form is favored,

2931.78.text:
do you mean in all
cases or just...

2934.25.text:
Ahern: In this particular
case, but in general,

2936.43.text:
when you can arrange
things away from each other,

2938.25.text: you're going to be better off.

2939.15.text:
I'm just illustrating
this as one example

2941.59.text:
to show you how a
boat vs. a chair form

2946.43.text:

to put these in chair

2948.15.text: or boat form on the exam?

2949.58.text:
Ahern: Will we need to
draw a chair or boat form

2951.45.text:
on the exam and get all
these axiology and so forth

2953.25.text:
and the answer is no, I
think that's kinda busy work.

2956.05.text:
But I think you should certainly
know what a chair form is.

2959.09.text:
And I think you should
know what a boat form

2960.40.text:
and why one vs. the
other might be favored.

2964.12.text:

it, but how do you determine

2966.78.text:
whether it's an alpha

2970.97.text:
Ahern: The alpha
has the hydroxyl down

2973.68.text:
as we draw it and the
beta has the hydroxyl up.
